verses.text: Now about the collection for the saints: Do as I directed the churches in Galatia.
verses.comment: Paul instructs the Corinthians just as he did other churches, highlighting a consistent teaching authority among the communities. The use of 'saints' refers to all faithful believers, especially those in Jerusalem in need of support. This demonstrates the early practice of almsgiving and solidarity among believers.

verses.text: On the first day of every week, each one of you should set aside and save some of your income, as you may prosper, so that collections will not have to be made when I come.
verses.comment: 'First day of the week' is an early reference to Sunday gatherings. Regular giving shows planned, communal worship. Note the connection between Christian generosity, corporate worship, and the ordering of life around the resurrection day.

verses.text: And when I come, I will send those whom you approve, with letters, to carry your gift to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Paul stresses accountability and honor by sending trusted messengers. This shows the careful stewardship and universal concern for believers in need. The unity of the larger church is implied through joint responsibility.

verses.text: If it seems advisable for me to go also, they will go with me.
verses.comment: Paul submits his own participation to discernment, showing humility and shared decision-making with the local community.

verses.text: I will come to you after passing through Macedonia, for I am passing through Macedonia,
verses.comment: Paul's travel plans reveal his pastoral care and flexible guidance over the churches.

verses.text: and it may be that I will stay with you, or even spend the winter, so that you may help me on my journey wherever I go.
verses.comment: Paul invites practical support, reflecting the model of Christians supporting missionary work. This establishes precedence for later traditions of sending forth workers with prayer and aid.

verses.text: For I do not wish to see you now only in passing; I hope to stay with you for a while, if the Lord permits.
verses.comment: Paul yields his plans to God's will, showing dependence on divine guidance and the importance of local presence for strengthening faith.

verses.text: But I will remain in Ephesus until Pentecost,
verses.comment: Paul references Pentecost, a festival with deep roots in Old Testament tradition and significance in the Christian calendar. Maintaining sacred times is seen as edifying for Christian worship.

verses.text: for a wide door for effective work has opened to me, and there are many opponents.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges both opportunities and opposition in the mission field. The language of an 'open door' is echoed elsewhere in Paul’s letters to refer to successful ministry (see Col. 4:3).

verses.text: If Timothy comes, see that he is with you without fear, for he is doing the Lord's work, just as I am.
verses.comment: Paul’s concern for Timothy’s well-being reveals the Church’s protection of its ministers. All who serve do so in unity with apostolic mission.

verses.text: Therefore, let no one despise him. But send him on his way in peace, that he may come to me; for I am expecting him with the brothers.
verses.comment: Echoing 1 Timothy 4:12, Paul warns against despising younger ministers. Sending ministers with blessing and respect is a pattern for the whole community.

verses.text: Now concerning Apollos our brother, I strongly urged him to visit you with the brothers. But it was not at all his will to go now. He will go when he has an opportunity.
verses.comment: Paul respects Apollos’s freedom and discernment regarding ministry, modeling shared leadership and fraternal relations.

verses.text: Be watchful, stand firm in the faith, act like men, be strong.
verses.comment: The commands here echo themes of spiritual vigilance and perseverance, key elements for sustaining the community’s faith in the face of trials.

verses.text: Let all you do be done in love.
verses.comment: This universal principle connects back to Paul's description of love as the highest virtue. Love undergirds all Christian conduct, preventing legalism or harshness.

verses.text: Now I urge you, brothers, you know the household of Stephanas, that they were the firstfruits of Achaia, and they devoted themselves to serving the saints.
verses.comment: 'Firstfruits' is Old Testament language reinterpreted for the Church, now referencing the first believers in a region, blessed and entrusted with ministry.

verses.text: Be subject to such people, and to everyone who works and labors with them.
verses.comment: Paul calls for respect and obedience to recognized leaders and servants. The structure and submission here reflect a community with spiritual authority, echoing Hebrews 13:17.

verses.text: I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus, because they have supplied what was lacking on your part.
verses.comment: These men’s visitations and service embody the unity and interdependence in the wider Church.

verses.text: For they refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore acknowledge such people.
verses.comment: Mutual encouragement of spirit was central to the early communities. Honoring those who serve is an enduring Christian lesson.

verses.text: The churches of Asia send you greetings. Aquila and Prisca greet you warmly in the Lord, together with the church in their house.
verses.comment: The network of house churches shows early liturgical gatherings and personal relationships among Christians. Continual greetings represent universal fellowship.

verses.text: All the brothers send you greetings. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
verses.comment: The 'holy kiss' was a liturgical act of peace, symbolizing reconciliation and unity before sharing the Lord's Supper (cf. Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand.
verses.comment: Paul’s personal signature authenticates the letter and implies spiritual authority and affection for his readers.

verses.text: If anyone does not love the Lord, let him be accursed. Maranatha! (Our Lord, come!)
verses.comment: The phrase 'Maranatha' is left in Aramaic, reflecting the Church's ancient prayers for Christ's return (cf. Rev. 22:20). Paul's warning shows the seriousness of loving Christ—a mark of true faith and Church membership. The invocation echoes early worship and creedal statements.

verses.text: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
verses.comment: This blessing summarizes Paul’s prayer for the Corinthians, invoking the Lord’s sustaining grace over the whole community.

verses.text: My love be with all of you in Christ Jesus. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul ends the letter with an expression of personal love in Christ, underscoring genuine pastoral care. The theme of unity and love in Christ is the final word for all the Church.
